canonical_explanation.text: Animals and birds live in different places called habitats. A habitat gives animals food, water, and shelter. Birds have special beaks, claws, and feet that help them eat different kinds of food and move in different ways. Birds build nests to lay eggs and protect their babies. Some birds travel very long distances when seasons change. This is called migration. We should take care of animals and birds around us by giving them food and water and not hurting them.
rules: A habitat is the natural home of an animal where it gets food, water, and shelter
Different animals live in different habitats: forests, deserts, water, grasslands, and polar regions
Birds have different types of beaks depending on the food they eat
Birds build different types of nests using different materials
Migration is when birds travel long distances when seasons change
We should care for animals and birds by not hurting them and providing food and water

questions.question_text: What is a habitat?

options.text: A type of food animals eat
The natural home where an animal lives
A name for a group of animals

questions.explanation_correct: A habitat is the natural home where an animal lives. It provides the animal with food, water, shelter, and everything it needs to survive. For example, a forest is the habitat of a tiger.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A habitat is not a type of food or a name for a group. A habitat is the natural place where an animal lives and finds everything it needs like food, water, and shelter. Different animals have different habitats.

questions.question_text: Where does a camel live?
questions.explanation_correct: A camel lives in the desert. Camels are specially adapted to live in hot, dry deserts. They can store water and survive without drinking for many days. In India, camels are found in the Thar Desert of Rajasthan.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Camels do not live in water, polar regions, or dense forests. They live in deserts where it is hot and dry. Camels are called the 'Ship of the Desert' because they can carry heavy loads across the sandy desert.

questions.question_text: Which of these animals lives in water?
questions.explanation_correct: Fish lives in water. Fish have gills to breathe in water and fins to swim. They are found in rivers, lakes, ponds, and the sea. Water is their natural habitat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tigers live in forests, elephants live in forests and grasslands, and monkeys live in trees in forests. Fish is the correct answer because fish live in water and have special body parts like gills and fins to survive in water.

questions.question_text: The tiger is found in which habitat in India?
questions.explanation_correct: The tiger lives in forests. The Royal Bengal Tiger is found in the forests of India, especially in places like Jim Corbett National Park, Sundarbans, and Ranthambore. It is India's national animal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tigers do not live in deserts, oceans, or polar regions. They live in forests where they can find prey, water, and places to hide. India has many tiger reserves to protect this beautiful animal.

questions.question_text: A polar bear has thick white fur. This helps it survive in _____.
questions.explanation_correct: A polar bear's thick white fur helps it survive in cold, snowy regions. The thick fur keeps it warm in freezing temperatures, and the white colour helps it hide in the snow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thick white fur would not help in hot deserts, tropical forests, or rivers. Polar bears live in very cold, snowy places near the North Pole. Their thick fur keeps them warm, and their white colour camouflages them in the snow.

questions.question_text: Arjun visited a wildlife sanctuary and saw deer, monkeys, and a peacock. Which habitat was he visiting?
questions.explanation_correct: Deer, monkeys, and peacocks are all animals found in forests. Wildlife sanctuaries are protected forest areas where these animals live safely. India has many wildlife sanctuaries and national parks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Deer, monkeys, and peacocks do not live in deserts, oceans, or polar regions. They are forest animals. A wildlife sanctuary is a protected area in or near forests where animals can live safely without being disturbed.

questions.question_text:
Match the animal with its habitat:
1. Camel  2. Whale  3. Penguin  4. Monkey
a. Forest  b. Desert  c. Polar region  d. Ocean
questions.explanation_correct: Camel lives in the desert (b), whale lives in the ocean (d), penguin lives in polar/cold regions (c), and monkey lives in the forest (a). Each animal is adapted to its own habitat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct matching is: Camel-desert (camels survive in hot, dry conditions), Whale-ocean (whales are large sea animals), Penguin-polar region (penguins live in very cold places), Monkey-forest (monkeys live in trees in forests).

questions.question_text: An eagle has a sharp, hooked beak. This type of beak helps it to _____.

options.text: Tear the flesh of its prey

questions.explanation_correct: An eagle has a sharp, hooked beak that helps it tear the flesh of animals it catches. Eagles are hunters and they use their strong, curved beaks to eat their food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eagles do not sip nectar, crack seeds, or filter water. They are birds of prey that hunt small animals. Their sharp, hooked beak is perfectly shaped to tear meat and eat their food.

questions.question_text: A parrot has a strong, curved beak. What does it use its beak for?

options.text: To crack open seeds and nuts
To dig holes in the ground

questions.explanation_correct: A parrot has a strong, curved beak that helps it crack open hard seeds and nuts. Parrots eat seeds, fruits, and nuts, and their strong beak is perfect for breaking open hard shells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parrots do not catch fish, dig holes, or sew leaves. They eat seeds, fruits, and nuts. Their strong, curved beak is specially designed to crack open hard seeds and nuts to reach the food inside.

questions.question_text: A duck has flat, wide feet with skin between the toes (webbed feet). This helps the duck to _____.
questions.explanation_correct: A duck's webbed feet work like paddles and help it swim in water. The skin between the toes spreads out in water, pushing against it and moving the duck forward.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Webbed feet are not for running, climbing, or digging. They are specially designed for swimming. The skin between the toes spreads out like a paddle in water, helping the duck push through the water easily.

questions.question_text: A woodpecker has a long, strong beak. It uses its beak to _____.

options.text: Peck holes in tree trunks to find insects

questions.explanation_correct: A woodpecker uses its long, strong beak to peck holes in tree trunks. It does this to find insects hiding inside the wood. The woodpecker can tap on wood very fast to reach the insects inside.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Woodpeckers do not sip nectar, crack coconuts, or catch fish. They have a long, strong, chisel-like beak that they use to peck into tree trunks. They eat insects that live inside the wood.

questions.question_text: Sita noticed that a crow has strong feet with sharp claws. These help the crow to _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Crows have strong feet with sharp claws that help them grip and perch on tree branches, electric wires, and other surfaces. Their claws wrap around the branch tightly so they do not fall off.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Crows do not swim, dig underground, or walk on ice. Their strong feet and sharp claws are designed for gripping. They can sit firmly on tree branches, fences, and wires by wrapping their claws around them.

questions.question_text: Which bird has a flat beak that helps it strain water to find food like small plants and insects?
questions.explanation_correct: A duck has a flat, broad beak. It uses its beak to filter or strain water to find small plants, insects, and worms. The beak works like a strainer, letting water flow out while keeping food inside.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eagles have sharp hooked beaks for tearing meat, sparrows have short beaks for picking seeds, and woodpeckers have long strong beaks for pecking wood. The duck is the bird with a flat beak used to strain water and find food.

questions.question_text:
Match the bird with its beak type:
1. Eagle  2. Sparrow  3. Duck  4. Hummingbird
a. Long, thin (for nectar)  b. Sharp, hooked (for tearing)  c. Short, conical (for seeds)  d. Flat, broad (for straining water)
questions.explanation_correct: Eagle has a sharp, hooked beak for tearing meat (b). Sparrow has a short, conical beak for picking seeds (c). Duck has a flat, broad beak for straining water (d). Hummingbird has a long, thin beak for sipping nectar from flowers (a).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct matching is: Eagle-sharp hooked beak (to tear prey), Sparrow-short conical beak (to pick seeds), Duck-flat broad beak (to strain food from water), Hummingbird-long thin beak (to sip nectar). Each bird's beak is adapted to the food it eats.

questions.question_text: Why do birds build nests?

options.text: To lay eggs and protect their babies

questions.explanation_correct: Birds build nests to lay their eggs and protect their babies. The nest keeps the eggs warm and safe from enemies. After the babies hatch, the nest protects them until they can fly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Birds do not build nests to store food, play, or hide from the sun. The main purpose of a bird's nest is to provide a safe place to lay eggs and raise their young ones. The nest protects the eggs and chicks from rain, wind, and enemies.

questions.question_text: The tailor bird is famous for making its nest by _____.

options.text: Digging a hole in the ground
Sewing leaves together with thread-like fibres

questions.explanation_correct: The tailor bird is famous for sewing large leaves together using its beak as a needle and plant fibres as thread. It stitches the edges of leaves to create a pouch-like nest. It is like a little tailor!
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tailor bird does not dig holes, use mud, or live in tree holes. It gets its name because it 'sews' or stitches leaves together using its sharp beak and plant fibres to make a safe, hidden nest.

questions.question_text: The weaver bird makes a beautiful hanging nest using _____.

options.text: Grass and plant fibres woven together

questions.explanation_correct: The weaver bird weaves its nest using grass, twigs, and plant fibres. It skillfully weaves these materials together to create a beautiful hanging nest that looks like a basket. The nest hangs from a tree branch.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The weaver bird does not use mud, feathers, or stones. It weaves grass and plant fibres together with its beak and claws to make a strong, basket-like nest that hangs from a tree branch. It is called a weaver because of this weaving skill.

questions.question_text: A woodpecker makes its nest by _____.

options.text: Making a hole in a tree trunk
Building with mud on a wall

questions.explanation_correct: A woodpecker makes its nest by pecking a hole in a tree trunk using its strong beak. The hole becomes a safe shelter for the woodpecker to lay its eggs and raise its young ones.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A woodpecker does not weave, sew, or use mud. It uses its strong, chisel-like beak to peck a hole into a tree trunk. This hole becomes the woodpecker's nest where it lays eggs and keeps its chicks safe.

questions.question_text: Which of these birds builds a nest using mud?
questions.explanation_correct: The robin (or potter bird) builds its nest using wet mud. It collects mud in its beak and shapes it into a cup-like nest. The nest is usually built on tree branches or ledges. When the mud dries, the nest becomes hard and strong.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tailor bird sews leaves, weaver bird weaves grass, and woodpecker pecks holes in trees. The robin or potter bird is the one that uses mud to build a cup-shaped nest. It collects wet mud and moulds it into shape.

questions.question_text: What is bird migration?

options.text: When birds travel long distances to another place when seasons change

questions.explanation_correct: Bird migration is when birds travel long distances from one place to another when seasons change. They fly to warmer places in winter and return when the weather gets better in their home area.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Migration is not about building nests, learning to fly, or laying eggs. Migration means travelling a long distance. Birds migrate because the weather in their home becomes too cold or they cannot find enough food. They fly to warmer places and come back later.

questions.question_text: Which of these birds visits India during winter from cold regions like Siberia?
questions.explanation_correct: The Siberian crane visits India during winter. It travels thousands of kilometres from Siberia (a very cold region in Russia) to the warmer wetlands of India. These beautiful white birds can be seen at places like Keoladeo National Park in Rajasthan.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Crows, sparrows, and peacocks are birds that live in India all year round. They do not migrate. The Siberian crane travels from Siberia in Russia to India during winter because Siberia becomes too cold for it.

questions.question_text: Why do some birds migrate to warmer places in winter?

options.text: Because their home becomes too cold and food becomes scarce
Because they want to meet other birds
Because they need to learn new songs

questions.explanation_correct: Birds migrate because their home becomes too cold in winter and they cannot find enough food. Water bodies freeze, insects disappear, and plants die. So they fly to warmer places where they can find food and survive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Birds do not migrate for fun, to meet others, or to learn songs. They migrate because they need to survive. When winter comes, their home becomes very cold, water freezes, and food becomes very hard to find. They must fly to warmer places to stay alive.

questions.question_text: Which of these statements about bird migration is TRUE?

options.text: Only some birds migrate, and they return to their home after winter
Migratory birds never come back to their original home
Birds migrate because they are scared of snow

questions.explanation_correct: Only some birds migrate, not all birds. Migratory birds travel to warmer places during winter and return to their original home when the weather becomes better. This journey happens every year.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not all birds migrate - many birds like crows, sparrows, and peacocks stay in one place all year. Migratory birds do return to their original home after winter is over. They are not scared of snow; they migrate because they cannot find food in cold weather.

questions.question_text: How can we help birds in summer?

options.text: By keeping a bowl of water outside for them to drink

questions.explanation_correct: We can help birds in summer by keeping a bowl of water outside our house or on the balcony. In hot summer, birds get very thirsty and it is hard for them to find water. A small bowl of water can save their lives.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Catching birds, scaring them, or cutting trees all harm birds. The best way to help birds in summer is to keep a bowl of clean water for them. Summer heat makes it very hard for birds to find water, and they can die of thirst.

questions.question_text: Anita found a baby bird that had fallen from its nest. What should she do?

options.text: Take it home as a pet
Leave it alone and walk away
Gently place it back in the nest or call an animal rescue helper

questions.explanation_correct: If you find a baby bird that has fallen from its nest, the best thing to do is gently place it back if you can reach the nest, or ask an adult to call an animal rescue helper. The baby bird needs its mother's care.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wild birds should not be kept as pets. Leaving a baby bird on the ground is dangerous as a cat or dog might hurt it. Chocolate is harmful for birds. The best option is to gently put it back in the nest or get help from an animal rescue person.

questions.question_text: Which of these actions is HARMFUL to animals and birds?

options.text: Keeping water for birds in summer
Throwing plastic bags in open areas
Not littering in parks and forests

questions.explanation_correct: Throwing plastic bags in open areas is harmful. Animals and birds can choke on plastic or get tangled in it. Plastic does not break down easily and pollutes the environment, causing harm to wildlife.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Planting trees, keeping water for birds, and not littering are all helpful actions. Throwing plastic bags in open areas is the harmful action because animals can eat plastic by mistake and choke, or get tangled in it. Plastic pollution is very dangerous for wildlife.

questions.question_text: An elephant uses its long trunk to _____.

options.text: Pick up food, drink water, and spray water on itself

questions.explanation_correct: An elephant's long trunk is like a hand and a nose combined. It uses the trunk to pick up food, drink water by sucking it up and putting it in its mouth, spray water on its body to cool down, and even greet other elephants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Elephants cannot fly, and they do not dig holes or catch fish with their trunks. The trunk is used for picking food, drinking water, breathing, spraying water, and touching things. It is one of the most useful body parts of an elephant.

questions.question_text: A fish can live on land just like a dog.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. A fish cannot live on land. Fish breathe through gills, which work only in water. If a fish is taken out of water, it cannot breathe and will die. A dog breathes through lungs and lives on land.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fish and dogs live in very different habitats. Fish are adapted to live in water - they have gills to breathe in water, fins to swim, and a streamlined body. They cannot survive on land because they cannot breathe air through gills.

questions.question_text: All birds have the same type of beak.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Different birds have different types of beaks depending on the food they eat. Eagles have sharp hooked beaks, parrots have strong curved beaks, ducks have flat broad beaks, and sparrows have short conical beaks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Birds do not all have the same beak. Each type of bird has a beak that is specially shaped for the food it eats. A bird that eats meat has a different beak from a bird that eats seeds or nectar.

questions.question_text: The tailor bird sews leaves together to make its nest.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The tailor bird uses its sharp beak like a needle and plant fibres like thread to sew or stitch large leaves together. It creates a pouch-like nest inside the stitched leaves. That is why it is called the tailor bird.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tailor bird does indeed sew leaves together. It uses its sharp beak as a needle and plant fibres as thread. The bird pokes holes in the edges of large leaves and pulls the fibres through to stitch them into a nest.

questions.question_text: All birds migrate to different places during winter.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Not all birds migrate. Many birds like crows, sparrows, pigeons, and peacocks live in the same place all year round. Only some birds like the Siberian crane migrate to warmer places during winter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Many birds stay in the same place throughout the year. Only certain birds that live in very cold places migrate. In India, crows, sparrows, mynas, and peacocks do not migrate. They are resident birds that live here all year.

questions.question_text: We should keep birds in cages because they look beautiful.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. We should not keep birds in cages. Birds are meant to fly freely in the sky. Keeping them in cages makes them sad and unhealthy. We should love and admire birds in their natural habitat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Keeping birds in cages is wrong. Birds need to fly freely, find their own food, and live in their natural habitat. A cage is like a prison for a bird. We should enjoy watching birds in nature, not lock them up.

questions.question_text: A duck has webbed feet that help it to swim in water.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. A duck has webbed feet, which means there is skin between its toes. These webbed feet work like paddles and help the duck to swim smoothly in water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ducks do have webbed feet - there is thin skin connecting their toes. These webbed feet spread out in water like paddles and push the duck forward. This is a special adaptation that helps ducks live in and around water.

questions.question_text: All birds build their nests on tree branches.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Not all birds build nests on tree branches. Some birds like the woodpecker make holes in tree trunks, some birds nest on the ground, and some birds like penguins do not build nests at all. Different birds have different nesting habits.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Birds build nests in many different places, not just on tree branches. A woodpecker nests inside a tree trunk, some birds nest on the ground, some on cliffs, and some on building ledges. The location depends on the type of bird.

questions.question_text: The natural home of an animal is called its _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The natural home of an animal is called its habitat. A habitat provides the animal with food, water, shelter, and a safe place to live and raise its young ones.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is habitat. A habitat is the natural environment where an animal lives. Different animals have different habitats - for example, a forest is a tiger's habitat and a desert is a camel's habitat.

questions.question_text: A camel lives in the _____ and is called the 'Ship of the Desert'.
questions.explanation_correct: A camel lives in the desert. Camels are specially adapted to survive in hot, dry, sandy deserts. They can store water, have thick foot pads for walking on sand, and are called the 'Ship of the Desert' because they carry heavy loads across the desert.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is desert. Camels are desert animals. In India, they are found in the Thar Desert of Rajasthan. They are called the 'Ship of the Desert' because they can carry heavy loads across the sandy desert.

questions.question_text: An eagle has a sharp, _____ beak to tear the flesh of its prey.
questions.explanation_correct: An eagle has a sharp, hooked beak. The curved hook shape helps the eagle tear apart the flesh of animals it catches. This type of beak is common in birds of prey like eagles, hawks, and owls.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is hooked. Eagles are birds of prey, and their beaks are shaped like a sharp hook. This hooked shape is perfect for tearing meat. Other birds of prey like hawks and falcons also have hooked beaks.

questions.question_text: The _____ bird weaves grass and plant fibres to make a beautiful hanging nest.
questions.explanation_correct: The weaver bird weaves grass and plant fibres to make a beautiful hanging nest. The nest looks like a basket and hangs from a tree branch. The male weaver bird builds the nest to attract a female.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is weaver. The weaver bird is famous for its skill in weaving grass and fibres to create a beautiful nest that hangs from tree branches like a basket.

questions.question_text: The _____ crane travels from Siberia to India during winter.
questions.explanation_correct: The Siberian crane travels from Siberia (in Russia) to India during winter. It is a migratory bird that covers thousands of kilometres. These beautiful white birds can be seen in wetlands of India during the winter months.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is Siberian. The Siberian crane is a famous migratory bird that visits India in winter. It comes from Siberia, which is a very cold region in Russia, to the warmer wetlands of India.

questions.question_text: A duck has _____ feet with skin between the toes that help it swim.
questions.explanation_correct: A duck has webbed feet. Webbed means there is thin skin connecting the toes. These webbed feet spread out in water like paddles and help the duck swim easily.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is webbed. Webbed feet have skin between the toes. This skin spreads out in water like a paddle, helping ducks push through water when they swim.

questions.question_text: The peacock is India's national bird. Where does it usually live?

options.text: In forests and open areas with trees
In the desert with no trees

questions.explanation_correct: The peacock usually lives in forests and open areas with trees. It is India's national bird and is known for its beautiful, colourful feathers. Peacocks are found across India in forests, farmlands, and even near villages.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Peacocks do not live in oceans, treeless deserts, or snowy mountains. They live in forests and open areas where there are trees. The male peacock dances with its beautiful feathers spread open during the rainy season.

questions.question_text: A horse has hooves instead of claws on its feet. Hooves help the horse to _____.
questions.explanation_correct: A horse has hooves that are strong and hard. Hooves help the horse run fast on hard ground without hurting its feet. The hooves act like tough shoes that protect the horse's feet as it gallops.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Horses do not swim deep, climb trees, or dig holes with their hooves. Hooves are hard, flat coverings on a horse's feet that protect them and allow the horse to run fast on hard ground. They work like strong shoes.

questions.question_text: Which of these statements about bird nests is TRUE?

options.text: All birds build the same type of nest
Different birds build different types of nests using different materials
Birds do not need nests at all
Nests are only used for sleeping at night

questions.explanation_correct: Different birds build different types of nests using different materials. The tailor bird sews leaves, the weaver bird weaves grass, the woodpecker makes holes in trees, and the robin uses mud. Each bird has its own special way of building a nest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Birds do not all build the same nest. Different species use different materials and methods. Nests are mainly used for laying eggs and raising baby birds, not just for sleeping. Each type of bird has evolved its own unique way of building nests.

questions.question_text: During winter, Rohan sees many new types of birds near a lake in his city that he does not see in summer. These birds are most likely _____.

options.text: Migratory birds that have come from colder places
Pet birds that escaped from cages
Birds that were hiding underground in summer

questions.explanation_correct: These birds are most likely migratory birds that have come from colder places. Many migratory birds visit Indian lakes and wetlands during winter. They fly from very cold places where food becomes scarce in winter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: These are not baby birds, escaped pets, or underground birds. When you see new types of birds at a lake only during winter, they are most likely migratory birds. They come from cold countries to spend winter in warmer India.

questions.question_text: Which of these is the BEST way to help animals and birds in our area?

options.text: Catch them and keep them in your house
Plant trees, keep water for birds, and do not litter

questions.explanation_correct: The best way to help animals and birds is to plant trees (which give them shelter and food), keep water for them (especially in summer), and not litter (plastic and garbage can harm them). These simple actions can make a big difference.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Catching animals is wrong, sweets and biscuits are not natural food for birds, and not all animals belong in zoos. The best help is to plant trees for shelter, provide clean water, and keep the environment clean by not littering.

questions.question_text: The Royal Bengal _____ is India's national animal and lives in forests.
questions.explanation_correct: The Royal Bengal Tiger is India's national animal. It is found in the forests of India, in places like Jim Corbett National Park, Sundarbans, and Ranthambore National Park.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is Tiger. The Royal Bengal Tiger is a majestic animal and India's national animal. It lives in forests and is protected in many national parks and tiger reserves across India.

questions.question_text: When do migratory birds return to their original home?

options.text: When winter ends and their home becomes warm again

questions.explanation_correct: Migratory birds return to their original home when winter ends and the weather becomes warm again. When spring comes, food becomes available again in their home, so they fly back. This cycle repeats every year.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Migratory birds do return home - they do not stay away forever. They come back when winter is over and the weather in their home place becomes warm. Food becomes available again, so they fly back. This journey happens every year.

questions.question_text: Birds build _____ to lay eggs and take care of their babies.
questions.explanation_correct: Birds build nests to lay eggs and take care of their babies. Nests keep the eggs and chicks warm, dry, and safe from enemies. Different birds build different types of nests.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is nests. A nest is a home that birds build for their eggs and babies. It provides warmth, safety, and protection. Each type of bird builds its nest in its own special way.

questions.question_text: An eagle has sharp claws called talons. What does it use them for?

options.text: To catch and hold its prey tightly
To dig nests in the ground

questions.explanation_correct: An eagle uses its sharp claws, called talons, to catch and hold its prey tightly. When an eagle spots a small animal from high up in the sky, it dives down and grabs it with its powerful talons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eagles do not crack seeds, swim, or dig ground nests. Their talons are powerful weapons used to catch prey. An eagle swoops down at high speed and grabs its prey with these sharp, strong claws.

questions.question_text: Why should we not throw stones at birds?

options.text: Because it can hurt or kill the birds
Because birds will throw stones back

questions.explanation_correct: We should not throw stones at birds because it can hurt or kill them. Birds are living beings that feel pain just like us. We should be kind to all animals and birds and never do anything that can harm them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The real reason we should not throw stones at birds is that it can injure or kill them. Birds are living creatures that feel pain. Being cruel to animals is wrong. We should always be kind and gentle towards all living beings.
